Navigate to other release versions of Doxee Platform Process Engine

[6.6](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/process-engine-6-6)

[6.7](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/process-engine-6-7)

## Basic Structure
Doxee processes are stored in files called Infinica Process Definitions (IPD). The file format is based on XML and can be edited manually or with Process Designer.

A process definition consists of a header, optionally a number of settings like credentials or XPath function definitions, and a body. The body is the part of a process that can be shown as a process diagram, or graphically edited in Process Designer.

This chapter gives an overview of the process definition structure and describes the available components. For information on editing process definitions with Process Designer, please refer to the Process Designer documentation. For more detailed information about all components, including their IPD representation and general information about the IPD language, please see the Process Definition Reference.

## Components, Elements and Connections
The process body is made up of process components. There are two types of components:

#### Elements
The building blocks of a process. Elements include executable activities, loops, decisions and all other parts of a process that perform a function of some sort. They are shown as blocks in process diagrams.

#### Connections
These connect the elements in a process to control the flow of execution. They are shown as arrows in process diagrams.

Every valid process definition consists of at least a start and an end element, connected (either directly or indirectly through other elements) by connections. When executing a process, execution starts at the process’s start element and continues along the path defined by the connections until an end element is reached (or an exception occurs).

Exceptions, if not handled internally by the process, immediately terminate the process execution and return an exception element containing a type, an error message and the source (i.e. the ID of the process element that was the origin of the error) to the caller.

All process components have a unique ID. If the ID is not defined as part of the process definition, a random ID is assigned automatically. Process components may also have an optional name. The name is intended as a brief, human readable description of the element that can be used in process diagrams. If the name is not set, the ID will be used to label the element instead. Unlike IDs, names are not unique and do not have any naming restrictions.

## The Pipeline
At runtime, the process definition is augmented by the process execution snapshot (see [The Process Lifecycle](/doxee-platform/docs/chapter-8-the-process-lifecycle)). The snapshot consists of general information about the process execution and the pipeline. The pipeline is where all variables a process uses during its runtime are stored.

Variables consist of a name, a type and one or more values. A variable cannot be value-less a variable without a value is simply not set and does not exist in the pipeline.

As a rule of thumb, variable values are immutable. That means that a variable’s value cannot change without explicitly setting a new value for the variable.

Variables are set using mappings. There is no need to explicitly define a variable before using it - setting a new variable via a mapping creates it in the pipeline and sets its type and value. Similarly, setting a variable that already exists in the pipeline replaces its value, and may optionally also change its type.

When setting a variable’s value, the new value is validated against the variable’s type and may be converted. If validation fails, an exception is thrown. For example, assigning a random text string to an integer variable will likely result in an error unless the string only contains numeric characters. Likewise, assigning a text string to an XML type variable will only succeed if the string contains valid XML, but if it does, the variable will store the value in XML format, ready to be parsed by XPath expressions.

A mapping sets one or more variable’s values by mapping them from a source to a target. The source may be a literal (e.g. a text string or a number), a variable in the source pipeline or an XPath expression operating on the source pipeline. The target is always a variable in the target pipeline. Depending on where the mapping is defined, the source and target pipelines may be one and the same (e.g. when using a mapping element) or different pipelines, for example when a start element maps parameters passed to the process into process pipeline variables.

Mappings are explained in detail in chapter [Mappings](/doxee-platform/docs/chapter-4-variables-and-the-pipeline#mappings).

## Process Elements
The Process Engine supports a wide array of different element types, which are explained in the following sections.

### Start Elements
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 12. Start Element*

Start elements mark the beginning of a process, or a block (see below). Each process and each block have exactly one start element. At runtime, process execution starts at the process’s start element. Whenever a block is executed, block execution also starts at the block’s start element.

Also, start elements are used to map variables from the outside into their scope, i.e. into their process or block. A process start element defines which variables a process accepts from the caller, whereas a block start element maps variables from the outer pipeline into the block they belong to.

### End Elements
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 13. End Element*

The opposite of start elements, end elements mark the end of process execution, or of a block. Every process and every block needs at least one end element, but may have more than one in case their structure is non-linear, e.g. when using the decision element (see below). As a rule of thumb, end elements are the only type of element that does not have at least one outgoing connection.

End elements can map variables from their scope to the outside. A process level end element defines which variables the processes passes back to the outside world. A block level end element maps variables from inside the block to the outer pipeline.

### Mapping Elements
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 14. Mapping Element*

Mapping elements are used to prepare data and perform calculations. Each mapping element contains a number of mappings which read data from the pipeline and write new data back to the same pipeline. This can be used to replace the values of existing variables or add new variables, typically as the result of data operations or calculations on previous variables from the pipeline.

Each mapping element can define any number of mappings. These mappings are executed in the order they are defined. One mapping may therefore set a variable that is then used as the source by a subsequent mapping.

### Activities
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 15. Activity Element*

Activities are predefined execution blocks that perform specific tasks. For example, the Process Engine’s standard modules include activities for reading and writing from and to URLs, for transforming XML data and for rendering templates. Activities are typically defined in modules that can be installed together with the Process Engine as needed. Each activity provides documentation on its functionality, its inputs and its outputs.

An activity is used in a process through an activity element. The activity element references the activity to be called and provides input and output mappings to connect the activity with the process’s pipeline.

The input mappings of an activity element map values from the process pipeline into the activity. The activity’s documentation describes which parameters are supported by the activity. After execution, the activity may provide a number of output parameters. These parameters can be mapped back to the process pipeline using output mappings.

### Groups
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 16. Group*

A group is used to group together a number of process elements. It always contains a start element and at least one end element, plus any number of additional elements. These elements, except for the start and end elements, are called the group’s body.

To the outside process it appears as a single element. When it is executed, it acts like a sub process, propagating execution from its start element until an end element is reached. Execution then proceeds with the next element along the group’s outgoing connection.

At runtime, a group has its own pipeline. The group’s start element is responsible for mapping all relevant variables from the outer pipeline into the group’s pipeline. Only variables mapped this way are available in the group pipeline; all variables not mapped into the group pipeline are not accessible (constants are an exception, as they are globally available in the entire process). When the group finishes execution, the end state may map values from the group’s pipeline to the outer pipeline. Once execution leaves the group, the group’s pipeline is deleted from memory.

Groups can be used to logically group elements together in a process diagram. They are also useful for assigning an exception connection to more than one single process element.

### Loops
As of Process Engine version 6.5, the loop element does not exist anymore. Instead, groups with iteration targets can be used. Older process definitions are automatically updated accordingly when they are loaded.

### Decisions
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 17. Decision*

Decisions are used to branch process execution depending on the specific values of pipeline variables. Each decision consists of a number of conditions. These conditions contain XPath queries which are supposed to evaluate to boolean values. A decision can also have multiple outgoing connections. Each condition corresponds to one of these connections.

At runtime, a decision’s conditions are tested, one by one, in definition order, until a matching condition is found. The matching condition’s connection is then used to propagate process execution.

Each decision may have one condition which doesn’t define an XPath query. This is the default condition, and it always holds if none of the other conditions' XPath queries provided a positive result.

> Note

If no default condition is specified for a decision, a warning will be returned when the process definition is validated. The process definition can be instantiated without validation. In this case, the decision will throw an exception if a default condition is required (because non of the other conditions matched) but is missing.

### Wait Elements
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 18. Wait Element*

Wait Elements in the process trigger the usage of wait states. A wait state causes the process to wait for a specific event. Different types of wait states are available for waiting for a timeout, a new file in a directory or an incoming email.

When a process calls a wait element, it initialises the wait state using the provided input mappings and then changes its state to `waiting`. The process will then remain inactive until the requested event has occurred, which automatically wakes up the process. The wait element then returns any data provided by the wait state, ready to be picked up by the output mappings.

A wait element’s type specifies which type of wait state should be used. Depending on the wait state type, different inputs and outputs are supported. A list of available wait state types and more details about wait states in general can be found in [Wait States](/doxee-platform/docs/chapter-11-wait-states).

The wait element has an optional boolean property `uncache` which specifies whether the process execution should be removed from the cache once the process is waiting. Setting this to true frees up memory. This is preferable when there is a lot of data in the pipeline at this point and when the process will wait for a longer time. It also means that the execution data needs to be loaded from storage once the execution continues, which comes with a performance overhead. The default for the property is `false`.

The element’s outputs include the parameters interrupted, which is `true` if the wait state was interrupted rather than triggered by its expected event, and error, which contains an error message if an error occurred while the wait state was active.

A wait element which uses a wait state returning a payload also provides an output parameter result. This result payload is an XML and contains information about the wait state execution. The structure and content of this XML depends on the wait state type.

If a wait state fails while the process is waiting for it, an exception will be thrown. This can be changed by setting the `throwExceptionOnError` flag to `false`. In this case, the wait element will continue normally, but the resulting payload will contain an error message instead of the usual data normally returned by the wait state.

> Note

Before 6.5, wait states did not throw exceptions. The described alternative behaviour was the standard behaviour.

### Tasks
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 19. Task Element*

Tasks transfer the responsibility for a step in a process to another user or client. For example, a human task may require a human user to fill in a form before process execution can continue.

A process can only use tasks if a task manager was configured for the Process Engine. The users then use a task client application to view and handle their tasks. The standard Doxee application which combines both a task engine and a task client is Workplace. Please see [Tasks](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-process-engine-user-guide-tasks-1) for more details about tasks.

A task element always creates a new task of the specified type, using the element’s type field. Additional input parameters can be provided via the input mappings and include the potentialOwners and supervisors who may handle the tasks, along with any task specific parameters which depend on the task type. Which task types and parameters are supported depends on the used task client.

When a task element is executed, it creates the task and waits for it to be completed. Process execution is then resumed, with the task’s output parameters provided so that the process can access them in the task element’s output mappings.

Just like the wait element, the task element also has a boolean property `uncache` which specifies whether the process execution should be removed from the cache once the process is waiting.

### Scripts
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 20. Script Element*

Occasionally, something that is complicated to model as part of a process can be efficiently written in a scripting language. Processes may contain script elements that are executed just like activities and other elements. The scripts have full access to the process’s runtime information, including the pipeline.

Out of the box, the Process Engine supports scripts written in JavaScript. However, additional scripting languages may be registered.

A script element specifies the used scripting language and the script itself. The script can be part of the process or stored in an external file.

### Includes
![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 21. Include Process Element*

The *Include Process* element allows a process definition to completely include another process definition, called the *sub process definition*. At runtime, the sub process definition is executed not as a separate process instance, but as a part of the original process.

The element uses input and output mappings to map variables between the main process and the sub process’s start and end element mappings.

Since sub processes are included at instantiation time, independently of the actual variables that will control the process’s runtime behaviour, a process definition may never include itself, neither directly nor indirectly, to prevent endless recursions.

## Process Connections
Connections are used to connect two process elements. A connection always leads from one element (the source element) to the other (the target element). To the source element, the connection is known as the outgoing connection, to the target element as the incoming connection. Most elements have exactly one incoming and one outgoing connection, with the following exceptions:

- Start elements have no incoming connections.

- End elements have no outgoing connections.

- Decisions have multiple outgoing connections.

- Exception connections can be additional connections on any element.

### Standard Connections
Standard connections define the usual process flow. They lead from the start element through a number of other elements to an end element. During regular process execution, whenever an element has been executed, the Process Engine follows its outgoing connection to determine the next element to execute.

A connection may specify a delay which will hold process execution for the specified amount of time before following the connection. This can be useful for handling temporary errors. For more details, please refer to [Exception Handling](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-process-engine-user-guide-exception-handling-1).

### Exception Connections
Exception connections define the flow of execution if an exception occurs.

If an exception occurs during execution of a process element that has no exception connection attached, the process fails with an error. If, however, the process element (or a parent element, if the element is part of a group) has a matching exception connection, process execution continues by following that exception connection instead of the regular connection.

The target element of an exception connection is called the exception handler. It receives the exception as a variable named _exception and is free to use or ignore the variable. Process execution then continues normally along the exception handler’s outgoing connection.

Each exception connection defines the type, or types of exception it is prepared to handle. When an exception occurs, the available exception connections are iterated in definition order until a connection for the exception type is found. If no matching exception connection is found, the exception is propagated to the parent element (e.g. a group, if there is one) and that elements' exception connections are tried. If the exception is propagated to the process’s top level without finding an exception connection, the process fails with an error.

An exception connection may specify a maximum number of retries, which allows exception handlers to attempt the original operation a number of times before treating it as a permanent error. Combined with a delay, this can be useful for handling temporary I/O problems.

For more information on exceptions, see [Exception Handling](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-process-engine-user-guide-exception-handling-1).

## Conditions
While decision elements can be used to direct process execution to different branches depending on pipeline values, a common requirement calls for individual elements to be executed or skipped depending on a specific pipeline condition.

This can be modeled by defining a decision element that directs to the the optional element or directly to its successor depending on an XPath condition. However, a simpler way is to specify the condition directly on the element in question:

![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 22. An element with a condition*

If an element has a condition assigned, the condition is evaluated immediately before the element would be executed. If the condition evaluates to `true`, the element is executed as usual. Otherwise, the element is skipped, but execution continues normally with its successor.
